Art & Design

See the Art That Tavi Gevinson Collects

Abstract: The blogger-turned-actress lives in Brooklyn and is drawn to artwork about young women.

Caption: Tavi Gevinson in the living room of her Brooklyn apartment, which includes a framed piece by Jenny Holzer (upper left), a publicity still of Catherine Burns in the Frank Perry move “Last Summer” (top, center) and a photograph of Ms. Gevinson dancing at a Fashion Week after-party (right).

Without Context

Baseline (No Context):

A person wearing a colorful floral shirt sits on a gray couch with patterned pillows, against a wall adorned with framed pictures and a floor lamp.

alt4news (No Context):

A woman sits on a gray couch with colorful pillows, wearing a floral shirt and jeans. A lamp and framed artwork are visible in the background.

With Context

Baseline:

A woman sits on a couch wearing a floral shirt and jeans, surrounded by art, including a Jenny Holzer piece and a Catherine Burns still from "Last Summer."

alt4news:

Tavi Gevinson sits on a couch in her Brooklyn apartment, wearing a colorful shirt with plant patterns, surrounded by framed artwork.

Reference

Reference (Synthetic GPT4o-mini):

Tavi Gevinson sits on a gray couch in her living room, wearing a colorful shirt. The walls display a framed Jenny Holzer piece and photographs.

In Soccer, Power's Always in Play

Abstract: A new exhibition at the Arab World Institute in Paris explores how the game embodies political and social changes in Africa, the Middle East and beyond.

Caption: Larbi Benbarek, regarded as the first great Arab soccer player in Europe, from the exhibition “Soccer and the Arab World: The Revolution of the Round Ball” at the Arab World Institute in Paris.

Abstract: Turning to Brazil's indigenous cultures and folklore for inspiration, Tarsila do Amaral helped give rise to the country's Modern movement, a MoMA exhibition shows.

Caption: "Antropofagia" ("Cannibalism"), 1929, a seminal work of Brazilian Modernism by Tarsila do Amaral that is part of a new show of her work at MoMA.

Superheroes and Trailblazers: Black Comic Book Artists, Rediscovered

Abstract: A new book examines the lives of these trailblazers, who paved the way for subsequent generations of illustrators but were invisible to the mainstream in their own time.

Caption: Matt Baker's "Voodah" in Crown Comics #3, Fall 1945. A new book calls Voodah the first Black hero featured in a mainstream comic book. Six issues in he was replaced by a white version of himself.

After Rikers Island Closes, What Will Jail Look Like?

Food

Abstract: Cold brew isn't just for your mornings anymore. Spirits makers are moving beyond the fusty coffee cocktails of old.

Caption: A new selection of spirits is updating the flavor — and marketing — profile of coffee liqueur.

Without Context

Baseline (No Context):

Various bottles of cold brew beverages, including Jameson and Mr. Black, displayed on a neutral background with a jigger and citrus fruit.

Assorted bottles of cold brew beverages, including Jameson Cold Brew, displayed on a table with cocktail tools.

With Context

Baseline:

Reference

Reference (Synthetic GPT4o-mini):

Abstract: Since opening the restaurant in Oakland, Calif., in February, Nite Yun has followed Khmer cooking traditions that war and genocide nearly wiped out.

Caption: Ms. Yun replicates her mother's traditional Khmer recipe for kuy teav Phnom Penh, a noodle soup with minced pork, shrimp, crispy garlic and herbs.
